newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay shares in sharp rally, index at 34-mth high.
newsitem.headline: Bombay shares in sharp rally, index at 34-mth high.

text.p: ** (1005 GMT) Bombay shares end with sharp gains on first
day of weekly new account; local demand pushes up blue
chips, traders say
** Bombay top share index up 117.62 pts, 2.71 pct at
provisional 4,464.94 after touching 34-month high of
** Foreign funds buyers only in select stocks; rising
retail interest drives up shares in broader market
** Sharp rise in index-heavyweights, Hindustan Lever, SBI,
MTNL and SAIL contribute to jump in index, traders say
** National Stock Exchange index gains 20.85 pts at
Bombay stocks powered ahead on Monday with the broader market leading the rally and dealers expect the market to test all-time peaks this week on renewed demand from domestic and foreign funds.
"The main factor is liquidity -- there's so much liquidity in the system," said Mayank Khemka, research head at brokers C. Mackertich & Company.

The benchmark 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) surged to 4,478.19 -- a new 34-month high on Monday, piercing 4,450 for the first time since September 30, 1994. The index added 117.62 points to close at a provisional 4,464.94.
"The 4,450 was a critical level and now that the market has broken through we can expect a further rise," Khemka said.
Much of the momentum for the rally came from local operators bidding for shares in anticipation of foreign fund demand, players said.

"Some of the foreign funds are now turning their focus on dividend paying fundamentally strong small companies," said Vrajlal Dhank, a BSE member-broker. "Retail investors are also buying in these stocks."

Last week the index jumped 157.51 points, or 3.76 percent, to 4,347.32. A sharp rise in index-heavyweight stocks which entered a no-delivery period from Monday also contributed to the index surge, market participants said.
"There is a lot of speculative bidding taking place," said Kamal Kabra, former BSE president and member-broker.
He said much of the action was taking place in smaller capitalised stocks which showed volatile movement on account of the no-delivery period.
A no-delivery period occurs when a company closes its books and market players can buy or sell the company's stock without taking delivery of the shares.
Players get a longer time to close business during the period as against the usual weekly settlement.
Brokers said investor confidence had improved after many companies forecast a revival in business activity in the second half of 1997/98 (April-March).
"The confidence level is improving. It appears that retail interest is coming back into the market," said BSE broker K.R. Choksey.
"Stock markets always lead the economy. People are discounting good news that is expected to follow," Mackertich's Khemka added.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
